title: Crichope Linn Walk Route

images.caption: Entry gate. A stone arch used to be located here.

images.caption: Entry path. A bridge across to the other part of the path used to stand near by.

images.title: Rosser1954, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old carving on Skull Rock. A visitor from Norh Wales.

images.title: Rosser1954, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Crichope Linn red sandstone gorge and waterfall. The area has had some famous visitors. Walter Scott is said to have been charmed by it and chose it as the lair of John Balfour of Burleigh in Old Mortality. Robert Burns who knew the area well as a local and as a customs and excise officer, lived for a time at near by Ellisland Farm and is said to have carved his initials here.

images.title: Rosser1954, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Red sandstone arch

images.title: Rosser1954, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Waterfall seen from the stoner arch. Burley's Leap is above and Devil's Cauldron below. The Crichope Burn runs through.

images.title: The Chrichope Burn by Walter Baxter, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Rock formations in Chrichope Linn by Walter Baxter, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rock formations in Crichope Linn

description: This walk visits the Crichope Linn waterfall near Gatelawbridge in Dumfries and Galloway. Just to the south of Gatelawbridge there's a country lane where you'll find a sign pointing to the falls. Go through the gate and you can follow a footpath east along the Crichope Burn. This will take you through a wooded red sandstone gorge to the pretty falls. On the way look out for some interesting rock formations and 19th century stone carvings along the path. The path can get a bit muddy in the cooler months so it's best to wear some good footwear at these times.
